linkTarget.anchoringText: The Bakken petroleum system is in the Williston Basin that is a large sedimentary basin covering parts of North Dakota, Montana, South Dakota, Saskatchewan, and Manitoba as shown in Figure 1 (a). As one of the largest unconventional resources in the world and most prolific tight-oil plays in North America, it has approximately 7.4 billion barrels of technically recoverable oil as estimated by the U.S. Geological Survey in 2013 (Gaswirth et al., 2013) and original oil in place (OOIP) is considered to be up to 167 billion barrels (Nordeng et al., 2008).

image-wrap.label: Figure 1
image-wrap.caption: (a) Bakken formation in Williston Basin (Sorensen et al., 2010), (b) Stratigraphy chart of the Bakken petroleum system (Theloy, 2014).

formatted-caption.caption-text: (a) Bakken formation in Williston Basin (Sorensen et al., 2010), (b) Stratigraphy chart of the Bakken petroleum system (Theloy, 2014).

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: Stratigraphy chart of the Bakken petroleum system

2010. Energy and Environmental Research Center Subtask 1.2-Evaluation of Key Factors Affecting Successful Oil Production in the Bakken Formation, North Dakota. DOE Award No: DE-FC26-08NT43291 , May
2010 .

linkTarget.anchoringText: Thermal recovery is generally used to produce viscous heavy oil. Oil viscosities in shale oil reservoirs are very low therefore the mechanism to reduce oil viscosity from thermal methods will not be significant. Figure 2 gives an overview of the current range of reservoir depth and oil viscosities where the main EOR technologies are applied (Poellitzer et al., 2009). Literature reviews show that a typical Bakken reservoir is at least 9000 feet deep, and produces a light crude oil with viscosity less than 1 cP at reservoir conditions (Harju, 2012). The combination of these two properties makes gas injection the most optimum choice for Bakken.

image-wrap.label: Figure 2
image-wrap.caption: Screening of different EOR techniques based on reservoir depth and in-situ oil viscosity (Poellitzer et al., 2009).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Screening of different EOR techniques based on reservoir depth and in-situ oil viscosity (Poellitzer et al., 2009).

linkTarget.bib:
Poellitzer et al., 2009 Poellitzer
S. Poellitzer , Florian, T. Florian , & Clemens, T. Clemens
2009. Revitalising a Medium Viscous Oil Field by Polymer Injection, Pirawarth Field, Austria. Presented at EUROPEC/EAGE Conference and Exhibition, 8-11 June, Amsterdam, The Netherlands. SPE-120991-MS . doi: 10.2118/120991-MS.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The core sample used in the experiment was obtained at a depth of 11,340.07 feet from the North Dakota Bakken formation. It is 1 inch in diameter and 2 inches in length. The absolute permeability (to oil) is 1.8 μd and the average porosity is 7.5%. Figure 3 gives a visual description of the core sample in addition to a three-dimensional porosity distribution obtained from CT image analysis. The core matrix is considered mostly homogeneous with some localized heterogeneities that we identify as laminations parallel to the core face.

image-wrap.label: Figure 3
image-wrap.caption: The Bakken core sample. (a) Wax-preserved core plug, (b) 3-D volume reconstruction of CT-derived core porosity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: The Bakken core sample. (a) Wax-preserved core plug, (b) 3-D volume reconstruction of CT-derived core porosity.

figure-specific-caption.caption-text: 3-D volume reconstruction of CT-derived core porosity

linkTarget.anchoringText: In theory, miscibility pressure increases with increasing temperature. Because the coreholder had a pressure rating of only 2000 psi, the test temperature was lowered to 38°C (slightly above critical temperature of CO2) in order to achieve miscibility at pressures attainable within the experimental apparatus. Figures 4 (a) to (d) demonstrate changes in fluid behavior between oil and CO2 at an increasing pressure inside the aluminum tube.

image-wrap.label: Figure 4
image-wrap.caption: CT scans of CO2 and Bakken crude in an aluminum tube at 38°C and varying pressures at 0.625 mm spacing, 140 keV/120 mA. (a) Ambient pressure, (b) 1000 psi, (c) 1100 psi, (d) 1200 psi.

formatted-caption.caption-text: CT scans of CO2 and Bakken crude in an aluminum tube at 38°C and varying pressures at 0.625 mm spacing, 140 keV/120 mA. (a) Ambient pressure, (b) 1000 psi, (c) 1100 psi, (d) 1200 psi.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Because the core sample is low permeability and low porosity, standard coreflood apparatus and equipment is modified accordingly. As shown in Figure 5, the coreholder is wrapped with electrical heating tape and connected to a temperature controller to maintain a constant temperature at 38°C. CO2 is pressurized in a stainless steel gas accumulator and an ISCO pump is used to inject CO2 at 1500 psi at the inlet valve of the core holder.

image-wrap.label: Figure 5
image-wrap.caption: Schematic of experimental apparatus and equipment for coreflood experiment.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Schematic of experimental apparatus and equipment for coreflood experiment.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 6 explains several key steps for the experiment of miscible CO2 injection. The core sample is first saturated with decane and dried under vacuum for at least three days at an elevated temperature of 65°C to evaporate any residual decane in the pore space. Next, the core is fully saturated with dead Bakken crude oil. We assume no initial water saturation here. The oil-saturated core is then brought to a pressure and temperature of 1300 psi and 38°C. Note that this is well above the miscibility pressure measured earlier.

image-wrap.label: Figure 6
image-wrap.caption: Proposed experimental sequence for miscible CO2 coreflood experiment.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Proposed experimental sequence for miscible CO2 coreflood experiment.

linkTarget.anchoringText: The cylindrical core is 1 inch in diameter and 2 inches in length. Properties (e.g. porosity and permeability) of certain grid blocks in the Cartesian model are modified to recover cylindrical geometry of the core sample. Specifically, as shown in Figure 7, the cylindrical core matrix has a constant porosity of 7.5% whereas any other grid blocks outside the cylindrical boundary are assigned a porosity of 0 so they do not contribute to any fluid flow and storage.

image-wrap.label: Figure 7
image-wrap.caption: Single-porosity Cartesian grid (22 × 11 × 11) used in numerical modeling of miscible CO2 flood experiment.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Single-porosity Cartesian grid (22 × 11 × 11) used in numerical modeling of miscible CO2 flood experiment.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Table 2 shows that a close match to experimental saturation pressure is achieved with an error of less than 0.3%. Figures 8 (a) to (d) summarize the comparison between lab data and model predictions for both CCE and DLE conducted at 237°F. There is an almost perfect agreement with the simulated properties except for oil phase compressibility in Figure 8 (b). It appears that the simulated result matches more closely with the experimental data in the high-pressure range than the low-pressure range. We argue that both are in the same order of magnitude and therefore within the range of reasonable accuracy. Moreover, we do not anticipate large changes in pressure as the recovery process is not pressure depletion.

image-wrap.label: Figure 8
image-wrap.caption: Comparison between EOS predictions and PVT data from Constant Composition (CCE) and Differential Liberation (DLE) experiments conducted at 237°F. (a) Relative oil volume, (b) Oil phase compressibility, (c) Oil density, (d) Oil viscosity.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison between EOS predictions and PVT data from Constant Composition (CCE) and Differential Liberation (DLE) experiments conducted at 237°F. (a) Relative oil volume, (b) Oil phase compressibility, (c) Oil density, (d) Oil viscosity.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 9 is a PT diagram constructed from the optimized EOS model that has shown to be capable of reproducing the phase behavior of Bakken reservoir fluid. The bubble point pressure is labelled as a red triangle. Table 3 summarizes the final pseudo-component description and input for EOS calculations. Note that the fluid model created for live oil (2nd column) is then used in a two-phase flash calculation to obtain molar compositions of dead oil (3rd column) deprived of light, volatile hydrocarbon components. This dead oil is considered more representative of the fluid sample used for our miscible CO2 experiment and its composition is used as the initial input for the subsequent flow simulations.

image-wrap.label: Figure 9
image-wrap.caption: PT diagram from optimized EOS model representative of Bakken crude phase behavior.

formatted-caption.caption-text: PT diagram from optimized EOS model representative of Bakken crude phase behavior.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Three-phase relative permeability curves for a matrix system were generated using Brooks-Corey's equations, based on parameters given in Table 5 (Kurtoglu, 2013). Capillary pressure was neglected in the simulation because the experiment was conducted at miscible conditions. Figure 10 plots matrix relative permeability data in both water-oil and gas-oil systems.

image-wrap.label: Figure 10
image-wrap.caption: Water-oil and gas-liquid relative permeability data for matrix system.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Water-oil and gas-liquid relative permeability data for matrix system.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 11 reports the recovery potential of miscible CO2 flood for a Bakken core sample. A continuous CO2 drive is simulated here instead of a "huff n' puff" process. This experiment unfortunately stopped due to power outage midway during recovery. From the trend of existing data, we conclude that the miscible CO2 flood is able to recover effectively at least 70% of OOIP despite a small pressure gradient used in the experiment.

image-wrap.label: Figure 11
image-wrap.caption: Hydrocarbon recovery from Bakken core with CO2 solvent.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Hydrocarbon recovery from Bakken core with CO2 solvent.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 to 13 present 3-D reconstruction of a difference map of CT number at both energy levels for two different recovery factors. Note that all color legends have the same scale from 0 to − 100 to be comparable.

image-wrap.label: Figure 12
image-wrap.caption: Difference of CT number when oil images are subtracted from CO2 images at an energy level of 140 keV. (a) Rf = 20%, (b) Rf = 71%.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Difference of CT number when oil images are subtracted from CO2 images at an energy level of 140 keV. (a) Rf = 20%, (b) Rf = 71%.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 12 to 13 present 3-D reconstruction of a difference map of CT number at both energy levels for two different recovery factors. Note that all color legends have the same scale from 0 to − 100 to be comparable.

image-wrap.label: Figure 13
image-wrap.caption: Difference of CT number when oil images are subtracted from CO2 images at an energy level of 80 keV. (a) Rf = 20%, (b) Rf = 71%.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 14 shows that the compositional simulation model has the tendency to match closely the overall oil production and recovery, but not the early recovery period where CO2 diffusion is seen as a major recovery mechanism. It is also observed that the simulation model has a larger displacement efficiency, possibly due to the following simplified assumptions:

image-wrap.label: Figure 14
image-wrap.caption: History-match of Bakken hydrocarbon recovery with miscible CO2 using a base model of 22 × 11 × 11 gridblocks.

formatted-caption.caption-text: History-match of Bakken hydrocarbon recovery with miscible CO2 using a base model of 22 × 11 × 11 gridblocks.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 15 shows that CO2 injection re-pressurizes the core matrix, thereby restablishing a drive mechanism dominated by advection. Both wells are controlled by constant bottom-hole pressure (BHP).

image-wrap.label: Figure 15
image-wrap.caption: Pressure distribution (psi) from simulation of miscible CO2 injection. Left: initial condition; Right: constant BHP well control.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Pressure distribution (psi) from simulation of miscible CO2 injection. Left: initial condition; Right: constant BHP well control.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figures 16 and 17 present a temporal and spatial development of gas/oil saturation from the simulation model. Initial oil saturation is 1. Figure 18 shows evolution of global molar CO2 fraction within the model as gas injection process progresses. The dead oil contains very little CO2, therefore the CO2 fraction in the oil phase mainly comes from the injection gas stream. As more CO2 dissolves in oil, the oil starts to swell which leads to reduction in viscosity, as shown in Figure 19. It is also observed that CO2 permeates into the core matrix from the 1st layer where the injection well is completed.

image-wrap.label: Figure 16
image-wrap.caption: Gas saturation map from simulation of miscible CO2 injection.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Gas saturation map from simulation of miscible CO2 injection.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Light hydrocarbon components are preferentially extracted and produced whereas heavier components are left behind by the solvent + oil front. This is reflected through an increase in oil molar density, shown in Figure 20.

image-wrap.label: Figure 20
image-wrap.caption: Oil density (gmol/ft3) from simulation of miscible CO2 injection.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Oil density (gmol/ft3) from simulation of miscible CO2 injection.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Here we determine the appropriate amount of X-ray exposure for CT images to obtain enough signals from the fluid occupying the porous medium. A number of analyses were performed as shown in Figures 21 and 22

image-wrap.label: Figure 21
image-wrap.caption: Comparison of average CT numbers at 0.625 mm spacing and different X-ray exposure times per image, 140 keV/120 mA.

formatted-caption.caption-text: Comparison of average CT numbers at 0.625 mm spacing and different X-ray exposure times per image, 140 keV/120 mA.

image-wrap.label: Figure 22
image-wrap.caption: CT scans of air/vacuum-saturated rock matrix at 0.625 mm spacing and different X-ray exposure times, 140 keV/ 120mA. (a) 0.5 second, (b) 1 second, (c) 2 seconds, (d) 4 seconds per image.

formatted-caption.caption-text: CT scans of air/vacuum-saturated rock matrix at 0.625 mm spacing and different X-ray exposure times, 140 keV/ 120mA. (a) 0.5 second, (b) 1 second, (c) 2 seconds, (d) 4 seconds per image.

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 23 plots oil recovery as a function of pore volume of CO2 injected for different numbers of grid blocks in the flow direction. The recovery curves look almost identical in spite of differences in size of the simulation model. 95% of the original oil is produced when more than 10 pore volumes of CO2 have been injected. Majority of the efforts (6 pore volumes) are directed to recover the last 10% oil composed of heavier hydrocarbons.

image-wrap.label: Figure 23
image-wrap.caption: Effect of grid refinement on convergene for a simulation time of 10 days (4 processors).

formatted-caption.caption-text: Effect of grid refinement on convergene for a simulation time of 10 days (4 processors).

linkTarget.anchoringText: Figure 24 shows CPU time consumption and the total number of timesteps as a function of model size on a log-log plot. A linear interpolation of both parameters is made to estimate computation expenses of bigger models.

image-wrap.label: Figure 24
image-wrap.caption: Effect of grid refinement on numerical controls for a simulation time of 10 days (4 processors). (a) CPU time used, (b) Number of time steps.

formatted-caption.caption-text: (Effect of grid refinement on numerical controls for a simulation time of 10 days (4 processors). (a) CPU time used, (b) Number of time steps.
